message.content:
cs.CG, cs.HC, cs.GR, cs.DS, cs.PL. 

The paper discusses the design of typefaces based on mathematical theorems and open problems in computational geometry, which is a subfield of computer science that deals with algorithms and data structures for geometric objects. Therefore, cs.CG (Computational Geometry) is the most likely sub-category. 

The paper also mentions the use of these typefaces to expose the general public to intriguing results and hard problems, which suggests a focus on human-computer interaction and user experience. This makes cs.HC (Human-Computer Interaction) a likely sub-category as well. 

Additionally, the paper mentions specific applications of the typefaces in hinged dissections, geometric tours, origami design, computer-aided glass design, physical simulation, and protein folding, which suggests a focus on graph theory, discrete mathematics, and optimization. This makes cs.GR (Graph Theory), cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms), and cs.PL (Programming Languages) likely sub-categories.
